project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
As a person releasing an iteration from the planning board, I can now only select higher-level iterations for my rollover (incomplete) work to be moved into.

Currently we are set up: 

Unscheduled
Release 1
•Sprint 1
••Sprint 1 - Team 1
••Sprint 1 - Team 2
•Sprint 2
••Sprint 2 - Team 1
••Sprint 2 - Team 2
Release 2
...

When a sprint is over, if there is rollover, say Sprint 1 - team 2, I currently select the fix version for the the next sprint for that team, i.e. Sprint 2 - Team 2. It seems like now my only choices are "Sprint 1", which doesn't make much sense why it would be set up this way, since it's got to go to the next iteration, which isn't going to be a parent. Before you could choose any unreleased iteration, which seems like a more flexible option. I was under the impression that I was using the fix version/iterations as they were intended. I think I can work around this by initially creating the following sprints in the wrong place, then moving them to the right place in the hierarchy.

We are moving to GH 5.4.1 from 4.4.
fields.summary: Can't choose next iteration for "moving" items when releasing an iteration from the planning board

fields.description:
Statistic bar will calculate and include parent issue time remaining but will not be shown above the statistic bar in GreenHopper Plannning board if the parent issue have sub-task that consist of time remaining which will exceed the capacity of the statistic bar. 

Steps to replicate:
* create 3 issues with original estimate set to 2 days each
* create a subtask for each of the parent with original estimate set to 2 days
* put a statistic/capacity bar for time remaining with the value 10 days

!screenshot1.png!
GH will only show 4 issues placed above the bar but the total time remaining calculated is 10 days (which include Parent 3 time remaining).

!screenshot2.png!
if changed the statistic bar value to 8 days, the bar stay at the same place but this time, the total is correct which is 8 days for 4 issues.

GreenHopper view can't separate parent issue from its subtasks in the UI.
fields.summary: Statistic bar not include parent issue above the bar if its subtask exceed the value

fields.description:
Per ticket here: https://support.atlassian.com/browse/GHS-2112

When adding select projects to the "Allowed Projects" listing (under Administration > GreenHopper > Enabled Projects,) adding a project to the allowed list creates a request URL like this:
http://localhost:8080/secure//secure/SetAdmissibleProjects.jspa?decorator=none&listValue=10010%2C10000%2C

Where the response is a "302 Temporarily Moved," a POST content size of zero, and a listValue entry that keeps getting longer.  Eventually, the list gets so long that the page will not load due to an "HTTP 413 - Request entity too large" error.  (Screenshots + Dev console in Chrome attached.)

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
Business Justification as described by our users:
"I currently have 5 sprints running simultaneously. I have 2 full teams working off shore in Cebu. I also have 1 team that is a mix of US and Cebu team members. To complicate the mix even more, I have a team member in Kansas (in central time). We are close to having a 24 hour development shop. We are making updates into GreenHopper at various times of day (and night). However, the supplied gadget for displaying the hourly burndown rate is currently only reflecting progress one time a day. Therefore, most of the time the data is outdated and inaccurate. 

The gadget itself does imply that there are options to update every 15 minutes, 30 min, 1 hour or 2 hours. There is also a refresh menu selection which implies immediate update. These options are not currently functioning as labeled. As the Scrum of Scrum Master (and overall project manager) I need accurate and timely information to provide to my management team. My director is now looking at our dashboards and is expecting to be able to see how our teams are progressing at various point in time.

In addition, I see a big benefit to having a quick chart like this so teams can see the progress of their off/onshore counterparts. I understand there may be system overhead to run updates continually. Therefore, I would be able to accept routine updates every 2-4 hours as long as there is an option to do an immediate refresh. In addition, the refresh options in the gadget should be modified to reflect the correct options."

Thanks,
Ian
fields.summary: GreenHopper Hourly Burndown Gadget - Update Every 15 Minutes or as Scheduled

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
In GreenHopper 5.1, adding new issues to a sprint would update the original estimate.   This behavior has changed in GreenHopper 5.2:

http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/GHKB/Burndown+Chart+and+Version+Time+Tracking+Statistics+are+Changed+after+Upgrading+to+GreenHopper+v5.2

Previously, if tasks were added after the start of the sprint, the original estimate for the sprint would increase to include the time estimated for the new issues.  The red "guideline" would start higher, and trend downwards to zero.  In 5.2, adding tasks after the start of the sprint does not update the original estimate for the sprint or the guideline.

There are customers who expect the previous behavior, and for whom this is an unwelcome change.  This is a request to provide a control (XML configuration file, administrative control panel) to choose how to calculate the "original estimate" field.
fields.summary: Optionally allow new issues to update the "original estimate"...

fields.description:
When adding a master Version via the GH add (version) dialog the version summary panel appears to be positioned with respect to other master version via the alpha-numeric sort on the version name,

When adding a child version (sprint) under the master version the new version appears at the top of the previously added child versions. As most sites would add sprints sequentially (sprint 1, sprint2,...) it would appear to be more useful if the child version appeared below pervious versions (as it did in older 4.x GH releases)

The current order requires much tedious use of the arrows in JIRA Manage Versions screen

This might be especially relevent if GH 6.0 is seperating the "sprints" from JIRA "versions" and there is work in that area.

*Workaround*

You should find the correct order if you put in an end date and release date in the future for the next child sprint. The ordering is determined by dates, and it does get confused when there are no dates there with the result that it falls back to the JIRA Version order.
fields.summary: Child Versions are added in "reverse" order within the Parent version

fields.description:
I believe that GH should implement a top-level team concept. Having multiple teams pull from a single project right now is cumbersome. (See: http://jaibeermalik.wordpress.com/2010/07/22/using-greenhopper-to-manage-multiple-teams-in-agile/) This should not require custom setup to achieve. And it is frustrating our adoption. 

Having separate project per team does not work either, as then there would have to be a separate "bug project" where issues could be reported but not associated with a team. Howver, then the coordination between what bug is in which project would be a nightmare. Enabling multiple teams within a single project, just like VersionOne and Rally is the right way to go.
fields.summary: Enable "Teams" as top-level concept

fields.description:
We are in the process of moving a business with several mature products to JIRA.  Unfortunately they want to use a version hierarchy - but in a slightly different way that is currently implemented in GreenHopper.

To explain the method I will use a very standard version hierarchy below:

* {color:red}Release 1.0 {color}
** {color:red}Release 1.1 {color}
** {color:red}Release 1.2 {color}
*** {color:red}Release 1.2.1 {color}
** {color:red}Release 1.3 {color}
* Release 2.0
** Release 2.1

{color:red}Red{color}=Released versions

An issue is identified in Release 1.1 by a customer in the field.  
The decision is made to patch the issue in Release 1.1, 1.2.1 and 1.3 and to add the fix to unreleased versions 2.0 and 2.1.  
To track this work they will create the initial issue in Release 1.1 and will create clones for releases 1.2.1, 1.3, 2.0 and 2.1 to track the patches/fixes.

As a result the initial issue exists in Release 1.1, Clone 1 is created in Release 1.2.1 and Clone 2 in Release 1.3 and so on...

When an issue is dragged into release 1.2.1 using GreenHopper the "Fix Version" will be set to "Release 1.0, Release 1.1, Release 1.2, Release 1.2.1".

This will result in the versions containing the following:

|| Version || Contains Issues ||
|Release 1.0 | Initial issue, Clone 1, Clone 2 |
|Release 1.1 | Initial issue |
|Release 1.2 | Clone 1 |
|Release 1.2.1 | Clone 1 |
|Release 1.3 | Clone 2 |

What the users would like to see reported is:

|| Version || Contains Issues ||
|Release 1.0 | Nothing |
|Release 1.1 | Initial issue |
|Release 1.2 | Nothing |
|Release 1.2.1 | Clone 1 |
|Release 1.3 | Clone 2 |

This would be accomplished by adding an option to the GreenHopper configuration that would change the "Fix Version method" to set the Fix Version to the version the issue was dropped into and only the version the issue was dropped into... 
(i.e. Clone 1 would be set to "Release 1.2.1" as opposed to "Release 1.0, Release 1.1, Release 1.2, Release 1.2.1" in the example above).

I have worked with several companies that use this approach (or similar) for issue tracking and I hope this would be an easy modification to Greenhopper which would allow it to be used by even more users in even more ways.

Regards,
Jon
fields.summary: Add Greenhopper preference to set the "Fix Version" to the specific version the issue is dropped into.

fields.description:
IMPORTANT:  This issue was submitted to Mozilla as Bug #633505:
https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=633505
They indicated that this is a bug in JIRA.  Please see that bug report for more information.
I have copied the bug report below:

In the application Atlassian JIRA v4.2.1 and 4.2.4 (and others)
Agile Planning Board, List View

Firefox 4.0 beta 11 does not display a "line-through" attribute on completed
items like other browsers do.

Reproducible: Always

Steps to Reproduce:
1.  Go to "http://jira.atlassian.com/secure/VersionBoard.jspa"
2.  In the upper-right corner of the page, select "List" from the "Views"
pull-down menu

Actual Results:  
Firefox 4.0b11 does not display the "line-through" attribute on the "BAM-####"
number for completed items (this was true in previous Firefox 4.0 beta versions
too).

Expected Results:  
The completed items should appear with a line through (strikeout) the BAM
number.  On this website, you should see several completed items per page with
a line through the "BAM-####" number in the left column (e.g. BAM-2648).  To
see the correct rendering, view this page in any other browser (including
Firefox 3.6).
fields.summary: Completed issues do not appear crossed out in Firefox 4.0 and Opera browsers

fields.summary: Prioritizing issues efectively doesn't work when there are a lot of issues to rank

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
When releasing a version in the planning board, you want to move not done issues to other sprints. In JIRA 3.x versions with compatible GreenHopper (3.8) you were able to move those issues between the parent-child version hierarchy. It seems to have changed now, so in latest versions you can only move left over issues to the child's parent version (1 level up).

Assuming this hierarchy:

Sprint
 Child 1
   Child of Child 1
 Child 2
   Child of Child 2

If you attempt to release "Child of Child 1", you would like to move left over cases to "Child of Child 2", as they the same "feature". The bug is: you can only release to "Child 1" (the parent, 1 level above).
I have tested this in a fresh new instance, with latest JIRA + GreenHopper (4.2.3 and 5.4.1). I also had a screenshare with the customer to clarify this issue.

I'm attaching some screenshots for better comprehension
fields.summary: Level hierarchy between versions is not working as expected

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
Hour burndown chart is not rendering time spent properly when logging work in between the time after the start date of parent version and before the start date of child version.

Steps to reproduce:

* create version 1 and 1.1
* configure version 1.1 to be the child of version 1
* set version 1 start date to 1 Feb 2011 and end date 28 Feb 2011
* set version 1.1 start date to be 15 Feb 2011 and end date 25 Feb 2011 (within parent version schedule)
* create 2 issues with: (Issue 1 - FixVersion=version 1, Issue 2 - FixVersion=version 1, version 1.1)
* set original estimate for both issues to any values i.e. 50 hours (both will be 100 hours for time estimate)
* log work in issue 2 i.e. 5 hours in between the time after version 1 start date and before version 1.1 start date
* the time spent is recorded in version 1 (parent) but not in version 1.1 (child) and this is expected behaviour
* go to chart board-hours burndown chart for version 1, the line *Team Effort* didn't increase even the *time spent* has a value


If the log done within the start date and end date for either parent or child, the data will be rendered correctly in the chart for parent version.
fields.summary: Hour burndown chart is not rendering time spent properly

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
When saving a context for the TaskBoard, would like to be able to specify which columns are displayed for that context.

For example:  

Context 1: only show "To Do" & "In Progress" columns

Context 2: show all columns (i.e. "To Do", "In Progress", "Done")
fields.summary: Allow users to pick which columns will show in a TaskBoard context

fields.description:
We track time on sub-tasks, and have turned on Greenhopper's Time Aggregation.

My stories have the following Worfklow. to match our Kanban Task Board
Statuses:  ToDo --> In Dev (Server) --> In Dev (UI) --> In Test --> In Stage
Task Board:  ToDo --> In Dev (Server) --> In Dev (UI) --> In Test --> In Stage

but my subtasks have a much simpler workflow
Subtask Statuses: Open --> In Progress --> Closed

For any given parent item, its aggregated time remaining should be included in the total time remaining for the column it is in, regardless of its subtasks' statuses.  

Example: I have 1 parent item with a status of "In Dev (Server)".  It has 3 subtasks, each with "Open" status.  Each subtask has 5 hours.  Since the parent item is in "In Dev (Server)" I should see 15 hours remaining in the column header for "In Dev (Server)".  But I see 0 hours, unless I change my Task Board Mapping.

In this example, I could get the 15 hours to show up in "In Dev (Server)" if I change the Task Board Mapping for this column.  If the "In Dev (Server)" column included the "Open" status in its list of statuses to display, then the aggregates display correctly for that column.  But this is not really a feasible solution, because I could have "Open" subtasks under the "In Dev (UI)" column, too.  If I kept this task board mapping, then all open subtasks would add to the aggregate total for "In Dev (Server)", regardless of the subtasks' parents' statuses.

fields.description:
For a customer, we did an upgrade from Jira 4.1.1 with GreenHopper 4.4 to Jira 4.2.2 with GreenHopper 5.4.
After the upgrade, the GreenHopper charts are behaving very strange, rendering different graphs using the same data.
Included is a screenshot of a particular chart which is very important in the daily routine.

In the panels on the right side, the values are the following:
- Time Estimate: 5 weeks, 2 days = 5 * (5 * 8) + 2 * 8 = 216 hours
- Time Spent: 7 weeks, 4 days, 1 minute = 7 * 40 + 4 * 8 + 1/60 = +/- 312 hours
- Time Remaining: 2 weeks, 3 days = 2 * 40 + 3 * 8 = 104

On the chart however, this data is different:
- Time Estimate - Starting point of burn down = 216 hours = OK
- Time Spent - at latest point in the chart = 235 hours NOT OK
- Time Remaining - latest point of burn down = 104 hours = OK

We tried to find the cause and choose Time-Tracking Analysis. In this screen we summed the remaining times multiple times to assure we didn't make a mistake. The result of remaining estimates was every time 88 hours, exactly 2 days less than the calculations by Greenhopper. (Where are those days added? Is there a bug in calculating burndown?)

Calculating the other values by hand manually (by selecting the same 48 issues which are selected by GreenHopper) resulted in yet other values, different from panel and chart.
fields.summary: Data rendered in the Hour Burndown Chart is incorrect

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
GreenHopper is an insanely useful tool - to the point where I have used it for various management reporting and tracking tasks that are outside of its immedaite Agile remit.

The specific need I have is to have issues that belong to Released versions remain visible. I have currently worked around this by adding new "virtual" or "logical" versions (which are unreleased and ordered after all "real" versions) to the system and then use the standard JIRA Multi-Select field to add this special version to the issue in addition to other "real" versions and sprints.

This technically works quite well, and even had the added benefit of showing little green ticks when the issue is released in a "real" version. The list view still shows the "real" versions as in a multi-select scenario, GreenHopper shows the earliest version by version order.

However, we have found that this approach breaks in a number of scenarios that have ultimately made the workaround unusable for us. The problems are:
a) The in-line editing has no idea about the multi-selects, and changing a fixVersion removes ALL other selected versions - so we had to stop using this;
b) You can't tell the JIRA issue "Bulk Edit" feature not to touch certain version; reducing its functionality considerably; amd
c) The subtleties of the workaround is beyond our general user community and is causing confusion and information loss.

I can easily store the virtual "version" grouping information using many other techniques; however I am left with the problem of how to get the issues visible on the GreenHopper Planning (or Task) board.

My suggestion is to simply add a check-box to the "Manage/Edit Context" facility where you can select "Releeased issues remain visible"

This should default to OFF (the existing behaviour) and it is appropraite for the override to be available against specific Contexts that need it.

NOTE: GHS-945 covers off a much more significant rework of how fixVersions work in GreenHopper. It is possible that some of the solution being developed there (apparently scheduled for GreenHopper 6.0) could solve this problems - but it possibly still may not. I am therefore adding this as a separate issue so that:
a) It doesn't totally feature-creep GHS-945, and
b) It can possibly be implemented more simply and sooner as it has a much lower impact and development footprint.
fields.summary: Override "Issues of Released Versions are hidden" behaviour

fields.description:
Hi all,

I am currently working with GreenHopper within JIRA Studio (2.3).
I am working in a software company and we make software engineering and requirements engineering both with JIRA Studio.
We have one single JIRA Project for both kinds of work.
The developers work on the issue types Bug, New Feature, Development Task, Improvement and the requirements engineers work on the issue type Requirement.
Both roles have different workflows.
Now due to the fact that both work on the same JIRA project there are some shortcomings when working with greenhopper.
It is not possible to easily switch between both modes (development and requirements).
Currently we solve the situation the following:
The Greenhopper Template contains all workflow steps (from both disciplines). The developers hide all steps that are for the requirements engineers and the requriements engineers hide all steps that are for the developers.
Further we created two contexts "Development" and "Requirements" that only show the issues types that belong to the users role.
So the problems are the following:
* The hiding of the "not needed" fields must be done manually by each user
* A user that has work to do in both roles (e.g. development lead of the project) has no chance to switch unless he/she adds the hidden fields again.
* It is not possible to provide such settings globally. It must be configured per project per user

What I suggest:
A new setting maybe called "view" that allows the greenhopper admin to define multiple views on workflow basis. I imaging that I can set a template per workflow and in Greenhopper I can then choose what role I have and then I see my templates and my issues. People that have multiple roles can easily switch between those.

I hope you find this meaningful.

Regards,
Florian
fields.summary: Multiple views on a project

fields.description:
Situation:
When using the GreenHopper task board in Compact/Kanban mode, trying to release from the gear menu in the Done column the following error message appears: "Error - No editable Issues matching the column mapping were found."

Explanation:
Under the Done column of the GH Task Board is showing issues with workflow step Closed, but Closed issues by default are not editable.

Resolution:
Follow the instruction on [Allow editing of Closed Issues|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Allow+editing+of+Closed+Issues] to fix the problem. Basically:
    * Go to Administration > Workflows
    * Create a draft for the workflow
    * Select View properties of the Closed step
    * Remove the jira.issue.editable property configured there

Bug:
That works, however even with the default workflow selected it is possible to release from the planning board. I'm not sure what the planning board does differently compared to the task board, but for some reason it is able to perform the release.

The Release works fine in the Planning Board, but in the Task Board when using Kanban you are greeted with the Error message, so you are not able to perform the release.

*Workaround*

change your workflow and Task Board Mapping to ensure the Done column is not "Closed" but simply "Resolved". That way you can use the Release mechanism.
fields.summary: Cannot Release from Task Board using Kanban view

fields.description:
Currently when ranking is enabled, if you create a new card on the Planning Board with a card selected, the newly-created card is inserted above the select card. On the Task Board this doesn't occur, however, (it shows at the bottom of the To Do list) and it's not really immediately obvious as to _why_.

A customer raised this as a support issue, and gave a very well thought-out response as to why at least the option to put newly-created cards above the selected card (or at the very top of the list) should exist:

{quote}
The scenario that our Scrum master is interested in is pretty constrained. Being able to add new bugs during a sprint is part of Scrum. Having them added to to top of the sprint backlog is how it's typically done (not just at our company — it's a common practice). I don't think that items need to be inserted directly into either the In Progress or Done columns. I don't think that sorting needs to be supported in the To Do column. Based on the scenario and Scrum practice, the only change needed is the ability to add a Bug to the top of the list (by selecting the top existing item in the list).

Further, Rank, which is a custom field, is kept invisible to the user. All the user is interested in is order of issues — the rank field is a way of supporting a sortable list, and the the specific values that it contains aren't of interest. That is, if four issues are given ranks values or 1, 2, 3, and 4, they will sort in the same order if they are instead given values of 2, 17, 22, and 48. The value doesn't matter.

The task view is showing the same issues as the planning view (for a given version, for example), but divided into three columns based on status. Does the rank value currently remain unchanged when issues are moved across the three columns? Or is it changing to reflect which items are moved across the columns first? (I actually have no idea, but it doesn't look like it's changing to me.)

If the rank value doesn't change when moving across columns (and this is a big "if"), then the rank value will preserve the list order regardless of which column an issue is in. That is, when a new issue is inserted at the top of the to do list, the rank values could be updated behind the scenes exactly as they are when a new issue is inserted at the top of the planning board list. The fact that I can insert a new issue at the top of the planning board list, switch to task board, and see the newly added item at the top of the To Do list suggests that this would be technically possible. That is, it appears that rank applies to all of the issues in a given version and is used to preserve the order. (FWIW, this suggests to me that the answer to your question is that yes, the rank of the cards in the other column should potentially change, but this is invisible to the user as it is done in a way that preserves the order of items in the list. As well, dragging the bug over to the In Progress column should behave the same way it would if it were a previously existing issue, or if it were one newly added in the Planning Board.)
{quote}
fields.summary: Option for new issues created on Task Board's To Do list to be added above selected card

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:
* Go to the Task Board
* Select a version (eg version 'A') for your Task Board
* Have issues in your 'Done' column
* Select 'Release' from the dropdown
* Set the Version Name to 'B'
* Click 'Release'

My expectation would be that Version 'B' would be created with a parent version of 'A'

Current behaviour: Version 'B' created without any parent version

As a user you then have to Unrelease Version B before setting the parent version, and then releasing it again.
fields.summary: When releasing a version from the 'Release' dropdown option on the taskboard, the parent version isn't set

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
When the browser height is smaller, various modal dialogues' (for example, the "New Card" button in greenhopper) buttons are below the browser's viewport and the browser is unable to scroll to see them.

The attached screenshot displays the problem -- note the lack of scrollbar on the right.  My screen resolution on my laptop, from which the screenshot is taken, is 1280x800.

The forum thread at the following link also describes the problem:
http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?threadID=49969&tstart=0
fields.summary: Buttons on modal dialogues can be inaccessible on small screens
